text:
STEVE HARAGUCHI: My
name is Steve Haraguchi, and I'm the director
of AI programs here. We launched this program
about two years ago.

And so we'll be
talking a little bit about the AI program, what it
entails, what classes we offer.

But the feature
of today's webinar is really to showcase
some projects that happen in a specific
course of ours, which

is one of our favorite and most
fun courses, Natural Language Understanding, which is led
by Professor Chris Potts.

So before we dive in and
I introduce the speakers, a little bit about our program.

This program was created
in September, 2019. So we're coming up on--

what is that? Coming up on three years. And the idea of this program
was a little bit different

from a lot of
professional education or a lot of online education
that previously existed in

that all of these
professional courses are directly based off
of graduate-level courses

at Stanford. And so we do use the lectures,
and many of the same lecture

videos and content, from
the graduate-level courses at Stanford. And then we create a mix
of programming assignments

and written assignments
that are also taken from the graduate
courses to give what we believe to be a very high level, very
rigorous, and very intensive

professional education program. And we make some slight
differences and adjustments to the course material just
to give working professionals

a little bit of
added flexibility, both in the way that
they schedule and choose

to take the courses, as well
as a little bit of flexibility in terms of how they go about
completing the assignments,

knowing that working
professionals are likely to have very busy
schedules, family schedules.

And so we try to build in
a little bit of flexibility into how you can go about
completing the courses.

I'm going to talk a
lot about the details at the end of this presentation. We'll have a sort of open
Q&A about the program itself.

But really, just
quickly at present, our program offers
six courses covering

the base foundational AI
techniques to foundational

approaches to machine
learning, but really diving under the hood
of a lot of algorithms that you likely have used or
may be learning about elsewhere.

As well as electives. We like to think of
more elective courses with two options around
natural language processing

and understanding. We've recently added a
reinforcement learning course, as well as the machine
learning with graphs course.

The target audience
for this program is practicing
scientists and engineers who are seeking a very in-depth,
foundational knowledge of AI.

So most of our classes,
you're actually not using common
packages for a lot of machine learning approaches.

You're actually developing
them from scratch, with the rationale and
the approach being,

by really
understanding what goes under the hood of a lot
of modern approaches,

it puts you in the
best position to deeply understand what's happening,
to put them into practice,

to apply them to your work. As well as, potentially,
to invent new approaches

in your future. So with that, though,
today's main feature

is to hear from two learners
who completed the program. So they actually can speak to
their experience completing

three classes to complete
the professional certificate. But we'll feature
their experience in one of our classes, which is
Natural Language Understanding.

So our two students
are Navdeep and Annika. Navdeep will be first. The Natural Language
Understanding class

is actually next offered
beginning in about two weeks, January 24th. All the classes are 10 weeks.

And you can see the topics here
that this course focuses on. It takes a broad view of many
different natural language

understanding
approaches as it relates to word representations,
natural language inference.

You can see all the topics here. Modern, sort of contextual,
word representations, as well as

how to put together
an NLU project. So in addition to assignments
that take place in this class,

there's also an
open-ended project that is a topic of
your own choosing.

You'll actually pick a
topic related to the course material that is most
interesting to you,

find and select the data set,
and put together a project. And in this class,
we have the option

of doing a project in groups or
doing a project individually.

So what we've
decided to do here, since this is our next
class that's starting, is, again, we've invited
Navdeep and Annika

here to share a little bit about
what they did in this class. They'll each have about
10 minutes to share

what they did in the Natural
Language Understanding class. They'll talk a little bit about
their experience in the course

and, potentially,
broadly in the program. And we'll have plenty of time
for questions and answers at the end, both
about our program

generally as well as about
their projects, what they did, what they learned, and how
they may be applying what they

learned to their work today. So before I introduce Navdeep,
who's our first speaker,

I just want to really
thank both of them for making the time to prepare
a couple of slides for you

all to see today, as well
as for taking the time to set aside the hour
to join this webinar

and talk a little bit
about their experience in the program. So with that, as
I mentioned, we'll go into more detail
of the program

at the very end of this. But without further ado-- Oh. Here's one slide
about the projects.

They are open-ended,
and they're free choice. And you actually can complete
these projects on a work topic.

So I'm actually not sure if
Navdeep or Annika created projects related to
their day-to-day work.

But that is something
that folks are able to do. So you can actually do
it within the context

of your current
employment if you'd like. So without further
ado, I'll turn it over

to Navdeep, who will share a
little bit about his project. And we'll have time for
a couple of questions about his project at the
end of his presentation

before we move on to Annika. But then, after that,
at the very end, we'll have plenty of time
to talk about the program.

So Navdeep, if you
can hear us, feel free to go live here
with your camera and mic

and start to share. NAVDEEP JAIN: Yeah. Sounds good. Thanks, Steve, and
thanks for introducing.

Hello, everyone. So I'm Navdeep Jain,
and as mentioned, this was my paper,
Customer Sentiment

Analysis using Weak Supervision
for Customer-Agent Chat. It's something I worked
on as a part of XCS224U,

and I'll be sharing more
details about that, as well as-- this was my third course in
the professional certificate.

So I'll give some overview
about it, as well. So a little bit about myself.

I am Navdeep Jain. I work as a lead research
engineer in the applied AI

research team at Comcast. If you are not familiar with
Comcast or what type of company

it is, it is the US's largest
internet and cable provider company.

And we have multiple
verticals on which AI focuses.

So until recently, my focus
had been on voice and audio.

And most recently,
my role has changed, where I'll be more
focused towards chatbots.

So that is a bit about me. Now moving to this
particular course.

I have two slides on XCS224U. One is the key learning,
and then the second one

is focusing particularly on
the project that I've worked on

and how I came up with
the idea for that project. So again, you can
find lots of details

about the course
when you sign up.

You can find lots of
details just by looking at YouTube videos as well.

But here are a few things
that I think you perhaps won't get just by looking at videos.

So the course has three
assignments and four quizzes.

I have three suggestions
for this course. Spend as much time as you can
on these three assignments,

which are mentioned here--
word relatedness, sentiment analysis, and pragmatic
color description.

The last question in
all three assignments is, build an original system.

My recommendation is
you spend as much time as you can making
the best system,

trying to win the competition. So for all these assignments,
there is a bake off,

and it's a sort of competition. So always try to learn, and try
to apply something original.

That will help you to understand
all the key concepts which are being used in NLP
recently, or even in the past.

And I think these are the key. When you have to come
up with a new idea, if you have a better
understanding of some

of these key concepts, that
will help you to progress better in the later weeks.

And again, I think one
thing to understand is, this course is 10 weeks. And when you have to come
up with an original idea

and write a paper, it
is not a lot of time. So that's why this first
three weeks becomes crucial,

that you spend lots of time
understanding the key concepts.

So that is one. My second, my personal best-- there are multiple
modules in the course.

But for me, the most useful was
this contextual representation.

This is the one many of
you might have heard about, models like BERT, RoBERTa.

But how they actually
work under the hood. And then, again, how you
can practically use them,

modify them. How you can train a
classifier using it, or how you can fine tune it.

All those things are
discussed in module four, so I highly recommend
that if that

is something you
are interested in, you focus particularly
on this module.
And this is generic advice. So it's a 10 week period.

Get ready for some
sort of adversity,

be it your personal
life or whatever. So for example, I'll
give you my example.

So I live in Philadelphia here
on the East Coast in the US. And while doing this course--

I live close to
Schuylkill River. And we had a flooding
in the Schuylkill River. It has never happened
in eight years.

And I was without-- I needed to evacuate for five
days, and things like that.

And then my work station,
basically a MacBook, was not working on
one of the weekends.

So the key takeaway there is
that all the assignments mostly end on a Sunday, so
don't wait until Saturday

to finish your course. Of course, you have those
five day extensions, and you can exercise some other
methods to not waste your time.

this will help you to better
prepare for the course. So those are key ideas about
three paper writing phases.

Now, the paper writing
phase is six weeks. The first four weeks
are concepts, quizzes.

And then the next
phase is paper writing. And there are three phases.

The key thing here is that you
spend enough good attention

in each phase so that it
helps you for the next phase. So if you spend a
good amount of time

writing a better
literature review, you can use that portion of
that review in your final paper.

And it can help you
contribute to a section called Introduction and Related Work. So the key thing
is, consider this

as a buildup to the
final paper and not as an independent entity.

So that will help you
to write a final paper. Again, if you have
never written a paper,

then it is really a
learning experience, because it can take
a really long time.

So prepare for each phase well. So for literature
review, as I said,

this is the phase where you
read how other folks have worked

on certain fields, and how
they've applied certain AI concepts, and things like that.

And you have to summarize it. The second phase is
experimental protocol. Now, always keep in mind,
you may get overexcited

with the idea of key learning. But it's a 10 week
course, so you have to make sure
that you finish

your part within 10 weeks. And experimental
protocol is the phase where you have to have the
full end-to-end pipeline ready.

Perhaps you don't want to use
all the data that you have. Perhaps you don't want to use
all the GPU time you have.

But you want to have your
full end-to-end system ready during this
experimental protocol phase

so that you are 100%
sure that you can deliver

a final paper after this phase. So this is a key phase
where, rather than spending

all your time building a
complete end-to-end system, you build a prototype
during this.

And also, the writing
over here will help you to write
data metrics and model

sections in your final paper. And then, the final paper. So the key thing for final
paper is, I would say,

spend some time learning LaTeX. I don't know if you
are familiar with it,

but it's another language to
write a paper which is simpler.

And it can be very
useful once you know it, and if you aspire to
become a researcher

and write lots of papers. Of course, there is some
learning curve involved, and I think this course
is a good platform for you

to get started on that.  Then, moving to my
particular paper and how I

came up with the idea. So my paper, as I said, was
customer sentiment analysis

using weak supervision
for customer-agent chat.

And I have made
this paper public, so you can find it on the portal
that is for the AI program.

But at the same time,
if you go to this link, you can read the paper. It's publicly available.

The key thing here is, as
soon as I decided that I wanted to do this project--

and luckily, I'm also part
of the applied AI research team here, and we have
an established NLP team.

So I reached out to our
head of NLP research and described about,
like, I'm going

to participate in this program. Is there any NLP
problem that we have,

but none of the
researchers are focused on? So that is how the
conversation started.

So even on the first
week, I had access to some data,
which was basically

actual customer and
agent chat that we have for Comcast customer service.

Now, we have this data, and we
didn't have any label for it.

So the question was, what
can we do with this data? And that is where it helped.

I had some sample data with me. And then, throughout the
course, as I learned concepts

about word relatedness,
as I learned concepts about sentiment analysis,
I could relate to--

OK, perhaps I can apply
this concept here. Perhaps I can apply
this concept here. So the process was, I would
have a meeting with our director

of NLP every couple of weeks
and bounce back ideas with him. And then, by the 4th week, I
had some good understanding

of what I wanted to do
with the data, which could be useful for the company.

And that is where-- I think Steve
mentioned this earlier. For me, I got lucky.

It was feasible for me
to convert this project as a work project.

So at Comcast, we have
something called lab week, during which you don't
need to work on things. You work on your regular days.

And this was my
fall lab week, which helped me to involve other
folks as well for annotations

and things like that. And then, the other thing
is, once you have some ideas, you always want to bounce back
with your mentors, which you'll

have here during the course. And Professor Potts holds
office hours every Thursday

throughout the course. So this is the
only unique course where you have the opportunity
to interact with the professor

himself. So you can bounce back the ideas
with him and can improve on it.

So my process was working
with Professor Potts and working with my CF
and mentor at Comcast

so that the idea is useful
for Comcast, as well. But at the same time, I
can submit that as a paper.

And a key contribution
of this work-- even though it may sound
like sentiment analysis is

a solved problem, you will
learn during the course that sentiment
analysis mostly has

been applied to customer
reviews for products on Amazon,

for products on Yelp. Or it has been
applied to Twitter. But it has never been--

because this is not easy data
to get in the public domain, customer-agent chat. So this was sort of
proprietary data,

and there is no large
scale data or analysis

available for this
particular domain. And the, the other
thing is, you will

realize that this data is key. But every concept that
we mostly use in AI

currently requires label
data, and acquiring label data itself is a huge challenge.

And that's where we
came up with the idea that weak supervision is
something that has been picking

up in the last few years. And we focused on
some recent work which

was done in the
summer last year, and we tried to improve that. So our paper takes
the previous work

to the next level, where
we apply it a different way to generate weak labels.

We also benchmarked our work
with the Google Cloud NLP API, so we can confidently
say that this has some value

rather than-- for an
enterprise, there's always a question of whether
we should build our own or use a third party API.

And using the paper,
using the work, we were able to justify why it
makes sense that, of course,

we can deliver as
good of a model. But also, there are
a few unique features that we can provide we wouldn't
get with the Google Cloud NLP

API. And we also performed some
domain-specific analysis on it. So this is about the
paper, and I'll quickly

summarize about my overall
experience for the AI

professional certificate. So I did three courses, and
these are the three courses.

Again, there are lots
of reasons why I did it. But COVID is also
one of the reasons.

This was summer 2020, during
COVID, with nothing else to do. And I think this was
the best use of time

that I could have done. And for Natural Language
Processing course, for me, key learning,
I was already

working on lots of
computer vision stuff. And I was working on audio.

and it takes concepts from NLP. But I have not
worked enough on NLP,

so this was a good stage for me
to take it to the next level. So I learned about
RNN-based models here,

transformer and attention. And attention is a
really key concept,

or one of the basic
concepts that has come out in recent years. With this, I was able to apply
attention in one of my models

and was able to improve it. And we were able to train
a state-of-the-art model for voice biometrics.

Then the other course I
did was in the winter. That was AI Principles
and Techniques.

As Steve mentioned, this
course challenges you to a very next level where
you don't use any library,

like PyTorch or anything else. You have to write
code originally. And if you really want
to challenge yourself,

both theoretically
and practically, this is a really
good course for that. And then the last one is
Natural Language Understanding,

which is, as I mentioned,
most of the detail. But for me, key
learning there was using

the BERT family of models. And I had a very good
time doing this course,

and I feel that the course
is completely worth it. So this has been my experience.

If you have any questions,
please let me know. Yeah.

Thanks. STEVE HARAGUCHI: Awesome. Thank you so much, Navdeep, for
your summary of your project, as well as your experience in
the course and the program.

Just a reminder. For anybody who has
questions about his project or his program experience, feel
free to put them in the Q&A.

And we'll take one
right here that I see. Why don't we take one
right here that we see

before we move on to Annika? So, question for Navdeep. "What's the end goal to get
NLP algorithms to understand

customer sentiment? What would an enterprise do
differently based on findings?" So why don't we take one
question, and then we'll

move on to Annika and save
future questions for the end. But yeah, Navdeep, do
you have that question?

What's the point? NAVDEEP JAIN: One
of the questions-- so I can tell as much as I can,
but I'll give you some idea.

The way we measure
whether a customer was happy with any
interaction, any services,

we use a metric called NPS. I don't know whether you
are familiar with it. It is called Net Promoter Score.

And you can read about
it, how this thing works. So the key idea--

and again, this is not
described in the paper, but we want to correlate
between sentiment and NPS.

So if a positive sentiment
relates to positive NPS,

then we can find
the conversation where we have the
positive NPS, and then we

can train agents to have
more conversations like that. So that is one of the use cases.

But yeah, I think
sentiment is a good clue to improve a user experience.

So that is where we are looking
to have some improvement.

STEVE HARAGUCHI: Great. Thanks, Navdeep. So I see some other folks
asking questions as well. I think we'll save some of
those till after Annika presents

as well and sort of do a big
block of time for Q&A. But up next--

thanks, Navdeep. Annika, who has stayed up-- well, not stayed up, but
skipped dinner, I suppose,

in Europe to join us today. Feel free to open up your camera
and your mic for your slides

as well. And Annika will also be
sharing her 224U project. And she also completed three
classes and the whole AI

professional certificate. So Annika, go ahead
if you can hear us.

ANNIKA HAMACHERS:
Yes, I can hear you. I assume you can hear
me as well, you know. STEVE HARAGUCHI: Yeah. Yeah, I can.

ANNIKA HAMACHERS: And
you can also see me? OK. STEVE HARAGUCHI: Yeah, fine. Everything looks great. ANNIKA HAMACHERS: So
thanks for having me,

and don't mind about my dinner. I always eat late. I'm more like that midnight
dinner type of person,

so [LAUGHS] no problem there.  Yeah, I will skip
this a little bit.

I will first start
with introducing who I am, because
I think I might be,

or I had the feeling
during taking the course, that I was a little bit
of an exotic figure,

particularly
considering my cohort. So it might be
interesting for you to get to know me a little
bit better before learning

about my project. Then I will present my project
quite briefly, and in the end

I will have it the other
way around, is Navdeep has. In the end, I will
conclude with certain tips

I will give to
people, particularly for people who come from a
similar background as I do,

and recount a bit of some
obstacles I encountered

during my way onto
the AI certificate, and some detours I
unnecessarily took,

and I could have prevented, if
I planned things differently from the beginning.

To start with who I
am, I am, I think,

one of the few people who
have taken this AI program who

does not have a background in
computer science, engineering, or any hard science at all.

My background is completely
from the social sciences. I have an MA in
Communication Studies

with a minor in Psychology
and German Literary Studies.

And I am on my way
to my doctorate, so my PhD studies,
in media psychology.

So not an engineer, not
a computer scientist, a mathematician, or
anything like that.

But I do have quite
a bit of background in programming, because
my work and my research

primarily focuses on
quantitative projects. So I came in touch
with SPSS programming

quite early, back at university,
and for my own projects,

incorporated Matlab quite early
on, and then switched to MR.

But to be honest, I
didn't really, really have much background in Python
programming, just a little bit.

I tended to switch to Python
only every time I wanted to do something with
non-ASCII characters,

data sets containing
non-ASCII characters, because that can be a pain in
the ass when you do this in MR.

But I'm not a professional,
or wasn't a professional, when it comes to Python programming.

Also, I'm not from the industry. I come from the public sector. I am a research
assistant currently

at the German Police University,
which sounds funny, maybe. But it's actually
a thing in Germany.

It started several
years ago that everyone who wants to enter
police leadership level

will have to obtain a master's
degree from the German Police

University. So what I do is that I teach
law enforcement officers who

want to be leading law
enforcement officers, and I do research in the field
of online radicalization,

and particularly there,
jihadi and right-wing online radicalization.

So I sort of already
came into this project with a strong interest
in fields like NLP

to handle big data,
especially social media data.

About my project, I
ended up doing something

completely different from-- or not completely, but
quite different from what I originally wanted to do.

My primary goal with which I
started was to do something-- yeah, so to have a little bit
of synergy effects for my PhD

project. So my goal was to
have a publication by the end of this course,
which can be a part of my PhD.

And so I wanted to do
something quite fancy. I had a strong, really
developed theoretical background

where I wanted to
treat social data for--

measure some sort of
emotional alignment

between different extremist
communities on the web.

However, this didn't
quite turn out. Navdeep already told
you that there's

three parts to
this cross project, and the first one is
the literature review.

I did this literature review
almost entirely on this, and that I wanted to do that,
but then found out, or had

to find out the hard
way, that it's maybe not ideal to start from
a theoretical model,

or only with a really cool
hypothesis in mind, and neglect

the facts of which data are
already out there or not. And I had to learn that
there wasn't really

much data which would
match my hypothesis,

and I would have
to do a lot of data cleaning or gathering
data myself.

And this course is
certainly not the place for this, because you simply
do not have time for this.

So I ended up doing
something which I found at first much
smaller than I originally

intended, but during
my literature review, I reviewed quite a few
papers suggesting systems

for emotion classification. And Navdeep already mentioned
things like the really powerful

transformer-based language
modeling techniques,

practice-based models,
and word embeddings that became popular recently.

And there were
quite a few papers making really strong points
about really nice effect

classification systems. However, quite in the
end, when I was almost

done with my
literature review, I came across a paper
which is also--

which I found funny--
also a paper that came from a former
cohort of this program.

Not the professional program,
but the so-to-speak real

Stanford program. And they discussed that all
those fancy classification

systems have a
bit of a bias when it comes to non-general
language contexts,

because we don't express
emotions or sentiment always in the same manner.

But the way we express
emotions or sentiments is, at least partially, a bit
dependent on the context

we're in, the peers
you're communicating with, the subcommunity you're
communicating in.

So these models try to
be a little bit imprecise

or misclassify a lot of material
when you are in a really

exceptional context. And I would argue that things
like a context where extremists

are gathering on the
internet, for instance, this is a non-general
context and a way

where emotions might not be
expressed as they would be, well, in general.

So what is needed there is
not only a nice algorithm,

but also, for feature
selection, dictionaries that portray or
are, so-to-speak,

domain-specific to
certain contexts. But you can, of course, not
generate such a dictionary

for every context that's
interesting for you and do this manually by
hand, because then, again,

you would only have the
dictionaries for the context that somebody has
already done this before.

So you would also be on
the look for algorithms that might generate
such dictionaries more

or less automatically for you. And there are some
label propagation

algorithms which have been quite
successful in the last years,

and which I found
quite promising. Unfortunately, those label
propagation algorithms so far

have never been applied to
emotion analysis or emotion

label generation, emotion
dictionary generation, but rather to sentiment
polarity generation.

So only differentiating
whether something is positive,
neutral, or negative.

And one of the most cited, or
I think one of the most famous,

sentiment propagation algorithms
is the SentProp framework developed by Hamilton
and colleagues.

And so what I wanted to do
in this course is something,

I think, quite
simple, or really, really targeted
and really focused

on this specific
question, is try to make the SentProp
algorithm work not only

So those were my two hypotheses. The first one is that because
the psychometric properties

of emotions and sentiments
are quite similar, I would argue that the
sentiment SentProp algorithm can

be leveraged to induce
domain-specific emotion lexica, and also, in turn, then
be used to describe variations

in the expression of
different emotions in diverse radical communities
or different communities

on Reddit. And the second hypothesis,
which is a little bit more

of a technical one. The SentProp algorithm
itself stems from 2016,

and in the field of NLP,
this is almost like-- I have the feeling, like, from
the last century or something.

Because this was before those
transformer-based embeddings

became popular, like RoBERTa
or BERT, or things like this.

And so the algorithm
is already working with embeddings, but not
with the transformer-based

embeddings yet. So my second hypothesis
would be that the performance of this algorithm
might be boosted,

or could be boosted even
further, by implementing or incorporating vector
transformer-based word

representations, in my
case, particularly BERT. However, I do not
know who of you

is already familiar with these
transformer-based models. They have a little
bit of the downside

that transformer-based
word representations come

in quite a different format
than the usual lookup table formatted word representations,
like models like,

for instance, GloVe or Word2vec. Because they are dynamic
representations which

take the context into
consideration, and the others are static representations. So you cannot just interchange
one model against the other

in your algorithm. But you would have to turn
those transformer-based word

representations into static
representations first. And this is something
which was quite new.

There was one paper-- I think I have the reference
on the next slide or the one

after that-- that proposes a
method for turning

these dynamic context-based
word representations back into static ones.

And if you do this,
you can easily apply them or integrate them
in the SentProp algorithm.

So that was basically
all I did, was taking two already
existing approaches,

merging them, and applying them
to my own hypothesis regarding

emotion detection. And I needed quite
a lot of resources

for this project, which, I
will point this out later on, can be something--

yeah, probably dangerous. So make sure not to be needy of

The first set of

which the SentProp algorithm

progresses. I will explain this

And for each sentiment,

with the help of the
Webster dictionary good representations

of certain emotions. In my case, I chose

already static, so to speak, standard word embeddings,
like love, train, and Twitter,

Word2vec, and then also
applied the turning

dynamic representations
into static representations algorithm proposed by
Bommasani and colleagues,

to the BERT model. Those were my three types

Then I gathered Reddit
data, and therefore, I

used the push shift app, which
is a quite straightforward method to gather those data.

So I could, within

Reddit data set

which didn't need much more
cleaning afterwards anymore. And then finally, which--

this also will be clearer
on the next slide. I needed so-called target
category dictionaries

against which I could test the
performance of the algorithm. Those were dictionaries that
already listed words associated

with either sentiment
polarity or certain affects. So I could measure how
well the algorithm actually

works by comparing the

dictionaries which have already

And so this is the scheme,

I built, which partly was done

to do everything, or

But what I did, or what
the algorithm basically is supposed to do,
is that it starts off

with a selection of
word embedding spaces,

either the static ones
like Word2vec or GloVe,

or the more fancy,
newer, supposedly better word embedding spaces
like BERT, which are then

turned into static
representation by the Bommasani algorithm. And what the SentProp algorithm
and its core functionality does

is that it takes
those embedding spaces and applies k-nearest
neighbor modeling to it

so that it creates a map or
a landscape of those words

and sorts them or opposes
them next to each other,

or far away from
each other, according to the similarity of context
in which they appear.

And so you can sort of
have a graph representation

of your entire vocabulary. And then in the next step-- and this is why we
needed the seed words.

We are starting random walks
in this embedding space from the chosen sequence
that you know or you said,

either representing the
positive or the negative scale of an emotion. And then you apply
several random walks

across this graph
representation.

And depending on how
often, or if at all,

one word hits or crosses
another word in this vocabulary,

starting from those
seed words, you can say that it's
either associated with this part or the
other pole of the emotion.

And you do this
repeatedly, several times. And by this, you can sort of
create your dictionary lists,

which you can then use to
describe your models later on.

And what I would
like to do further on is to also test this
against other algorithms

for emotion classification
at the sentence level, but I was not there yet. But what I could accomplish

of this course project

English domains, you are still better off
implementing the systems that

were proposed in the
original algorithm, so not relying on BERT

But when you want

then you actually have
this hypothesized boost in performance when you use
